column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity|centering
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) On an episode of Bad Voltage, three people discuss concerns about AI and Large Language Models, focusing on the 'free software complaint', which objects to companies like OpenAI using Internet data to which they do not hold the copyright and then charging users for access to models trained on it, as well as talking about proposed EU regulations on declaring LLM data sources.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) On a podcast discussion about AI and large language models (LLMs), the hosts examine concerns about AI companies not declaring copyrighted training data sources, with particular focus on new EU regulations requiring transparency about what content is used to train these models.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) In a discussion on Bad Voltage, Jono Bacon and Stuart Langridge explore fears surrounding AI and large language models (LLMs), emphasizing the necessity of transparency in their data sources, while commenting on EU regulations requiring LLM developers to disclose copyrighted materials used, highlighting both ethical and humorous aspects of potential corporate accountability.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The hosts of Bad Voltage discuss various concerns about large language models (LLMs), including the free software complaint, where LLMs are built by inhaling a shedload of information and then renting out access to it, and the issue of proprietary products being built on open-source data.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) The article discusses various concerns regarding large language models (LLMs) such as the use of copyrighted material during training, regulatory measures like EU regulations requiring declaration of copyrighted content usage, and the implications of potential legal conflicts between LLM creators and rights holders.
#Text=So there 's been a lot of hyperbole about AI , um , obviously a lot of things going on with OpenAI and ChatGPT and Bard and all these different things .
#Text=Um , but um there 's a lot of fear about AI , and what we thought we 'd do is get into what are these fears about AI , and do we think that they 're actually valid ?

#Text=Um , so one of those nice specific topics that we tend to cover on on Bad Voltage , but why do n't you Mr. Large Language Model run through some of these fears that people have been digging into .
#Text=Some of the concerns .

#Text=So yeah , first of all , before we get into it , slightly , um , the large language model thing is mostly a joke , but I think it 's useful to talk about LLMs rather than AI , um , because it keeps the discussion more focused .

#Text=One of the concerns which we 're not really gon na talk about is the sci - fi one about AI takes over and turns the whole world into a machine for making paperclips and grey goo , and it -- just whatever , right ?
#Text=It 's not really an interesting discussion because it 's not focused .
#Text=But I think part of that is because everyone has a preconception for what AI is .
#Text=It 's the Star Trek computer or it 's Hal or whatever .
#Text=Yeah , yeah .

#Text=Whereas if we talk about large language models , LLMs , then it 's clear that we 're talking about a specific technology rather than the sort of general nebulous concept of computers that can think , and it defuses a lot of the conversation .
#Text=So I think it 's worth talking about LLMs specifically because that 's what we 're interested in .
#Text=Yeah .
#Text=So I put together a relatively -- I -- it 's not comprehensive , but a relatively detailed list of concerns that people have brought up about this stuff .
#Text=And I 'm interested in your thoughts on each of them .
#Text=So in no particular order , there 's what you might call the free software complaint , where every LLM is built by inhaling a shedload of information and then renting out access to it .
#Text=And for pretty much all of them , the shedload of information that gets inhaled was n't owned by the people who did the inhaling .
#Text=Um , there 's there 's a big open question about whether it 's reasonable to download the whole Internet and shove it into your LLM .

#Text=And then there 's a second question about whether having done that , whether you can go " this is our proprietary product that you 're not allowed access to , but we 'll charge you for access to it " or whatever .
#Text=Um , yeah .
#Text=But that 's one of the objections .
#Text=And it 's it 's a particularly pointed one in the art world , um , for reasons that I 'd be interested in your thoughts on .

#Text=But I will point out before we get to that , that the EU are putting together regulation which will require people who create LLMs to declare the copyrighted material that they used in the training corpora , which I think is a really neat solution to this .

#Text=They 're not saying you ca n't do this , but they 're just saying , yeah , if you -- if you brought in copyrighted material , which almost everything on Earth is and almost everything in the LLM models probably is .
#Text=They have to declare that they did it , which means --
#Text=It seems fair .
#Text=It seems absolutely fair to me .
#Text=I do n't often agree with EU regulation stances , but this one I think is is very reasonable .
#Text=Yeah and I agree with it for I think two reasons , one of which considerably more noble than the other .
#Text=Um , the noble reason is , I think it 's good to provide transparency on where the data came from and so on .
#Text=Um , and this will also require the companies building LLMs to actually give a damn about where they get it from .
#Text=They ca n't just go " just set a crawler going and then whatever it pulls back , shove it in " .
#Text=They 're gon na have to document where they got the information from , when they got it , what permissions they had to it .
#Text=And that can only be a good thing .
#Text=And the second thing is this is the Schadenfreude one , which is not anywhere near as noble .

#Text=I am enjoying the idea of watching people at huge companies who build LLMs dancing in between saying , " yeah , we used all this copyrighted information " and getting beaten to death by Disney or saying , " we 're not prepared to declare where we got this information " to avoid being beaten to death by Disney and then getting beaten to death by the EU .
#Text=So , like I said , not particularly noble motive , but I think , like you said , I think it 'd be transparent .
#Text=Yes ?
#Text=Right .
#Text=Alright , so that 's one .
#Text=Do we want to go through these one by one , or do you want to just get them all out first ?
#Text=I think -- I -- I do n't know , what do you think we could do ?
#Text=I mean , are we covered on that one or have you got lots more thoughts about the source of training material for the LLMs ?
#Text=I mean , that seems uncontroversial to me .
#Text=Um , just -- just require them to declare where they got the copyright .
#Text=I suspect OpenAI will disagree with you .
#Text=I think the three of us will tend to agree on this one , oddly .
#Text=Yeah , yeah , I agree .
#Text=We , the three of us do n't agree on a lot , but I suspect this is one of them .
#Text=I -- I -- see , I think OpenAI , I do n't know if they disagree .
#Text=They would n't like to say they agree because they know it 's just unilaterally bad for them .
#Text=But Altman testified in front of Congress yesterday , said a whole bunch of things that AI should be regulated , that the models should be regulated etc. etc.

#Text=He explicitly avoided this topic , which , given the amount of prep I 'm sure went into testifying in front of Congress for the first time -- him leaving that out was , I imagine , not an oversight .
#Text=Yeah , it is the best I 've ever seen .
#Text=I was gon na say first time I 've ever seen a tech company ask for more regulation .
#Text=That 's not true .
#Text=Look at Sam Bankman - Fried , very famously asked for more crypto regulation while being a total grifter .
#Text=That 's -- that 's fine .
#Text=I -- look at how well it worked out for that guy .
#Text=Um , avoiding talking about this particular topic is the reddest of flags , to the point that I 'm expecting Jeremy Corbyn to come in singing about it .
#Text=And and exactly the reason for this is that they know they have n't got a leg to stand on .
#Text=Right ?
#Text=Well , I -- in my opinion , at least they have n't got a leg to stand on .
#Text=So we all agree that that , that people building , um , large language models should have to declare where they got all the data from , from it .
#Text=And if they find themselves in a position where they do n't want to do that because they 'll lose , then they can stop doing that .
#Text=Yeah .

#Text=I mean , there i- there is a related conversation around searchability of information like how Google handles this with the search engine , but I do n't I do n't think we want to get into that because it 's got nothing to do with AI .
#Text=Yeah , it 's kind of irrelevant .
#Text=Nothing to do with it .
#Text=It 's kind of related to the topic .
#Text=Yeah , exactly .
